He was transferred to the Heaonboburg Linpack Grant Medical Center after being found in the bathroom , on the floor at 8 a.m. , unresponsive . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : He had not had any recurrence . He had history of alcohol abuse in the past . ALLERGIES : MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION : None . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : A generally cachectic white male , resting quietly with his eyes closed . His blood pressure was 140/70 , heart rate 75 . His oropharynx was clear . His skin was clear . The neck was supple without lymphadenopathy . The heart exam revealed a normal Sl and S2 , regular rate and rhythm , no murmur , rub or gallop . Extremities - no clubbing , cyanosis or edema . The discs were flat . There was no retinopathy . He had a gag and good palpate movement . There was a right facial droop which was mild . He lifted his left leg off the bed , but no against resistance . He had clonus bilaterally with up going toe on the right , but not the left . LABORATORY DATA : An erythrocyte sedimentation rate 3 , hematocrit 44 , white blood count 21.7 , lytes within normal limits . The head computerized tomography scan without contrast showed a 3 x 3 x 5 cm. hemorrhage extending form the left Sylvian fissure and put amen to the left front oparietal lobe . There was blood in the bilateral posterior horns . HOSPITAL COURSE : On admission , he was difficult to arouse and there was a large volume of heme aspirate per nasogastric tube . His blood pressure was not elevated . The aspirates soon became heme negative and he was started tube feds and replated for phosphate , magnesium , thiamine , folate and B12 . An magnetic resonance imaging study on 07/17/92 showed a 5.3 x 4 x 4 cm. hematoma involving the basilar ganglion . The medial region of the hematoma was felt to be suspicious for tumor versus arteriovenous malformation . There was no enhancement seen in the region of the original cerebellar medullo blastoma . A cerebral angiogram of the left coronary artery was performed and unremarkable except for mass effect from the hematoma . An esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed and G-tube was performed at the same time . There was no specific gastritis and inflammation noted in the bulb and duodenum . This confirmed an 8 mm. mass which was bright on T2 and homogeneous in the right lateral segment and medial lobe of the liver , which was consistent with a benign hemangioma or cyst . The urine cytology was negative for malignant cells . Initially , the patient remained drowsy until Decadron was added to his medical regimen . He awoke significantly after that with increased alertness , ability to interact with his environment and follow commands . He has slowly made progress with increased strength on the right side and ability to walk with assistance . He was started on Dexedrine because there was a question of whether some component of his lethargy could be depression . This seemed to help him remarkably with increased activity . His Decadron has been tapered slowly to zero and his examination on discharge was as follows : He still spends a lot of time in bed , although easily arousable . He sleeps with a hypophonia , but occasionally will speak louder when he is in better spirits . His pupils were equal and reactive from 4 to 2 mm . There was some breakdown in saccads to smooth pursuit . He had limited vertical up gaze . He still had a significant right central facial droop . His gag was intact with palatal movements . On repetitive testing with Speech Therapy had not been able to swallow in a safe manner . Thus , he continued to be nothing by mouth and on tube feeds . He had approximately 4+ to 5/5 strength in the right upper and lower extremities . HE had an upgoing toe . On the left , his reflexes wee 2-2+ with a downgoing toe . He had right clonus , which was sustained . At that time , there was no evidence of a mass behind the hematoma . It was felt with his weight loss , that this needs to be relooked at in one month . Depending upon his head computerized tomography scan , he will proceed to a brain biopsy if needed .
